citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is an expired tube of Lidocaine and an expired bottle of Levetiracetam in the clinic room in building A. There is also
an expired bottle of Enalapril Maleate 5mg/ml in the medication prep and storage area in Building C. The Enalapril
Maleate is prescribed to an umbrella cockatoo named “Katie”. The Enalapril expired on 7/13/25 and is still being
administered to “Katie”. The use of expired medications is not considered to be a safe or appropriate method to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries since the expected results cannot be guaranteed. The facility must
ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must
ensure all medications used for animals covered under the Animal Welfare Act are not expired. The facility corrected this
at time of inspection by throwing away all expired medications.
Treatment sheets for 13 birds show multiple doses of medication prescribed by the attending veterinarian that were not
recorded as being given. Not giving the medications and supplements on the days and times that they are required could
lead to unnecessary pain and could further delay healing and resolution of health conditions. The facility must ensure the
use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries by giving prescriptions as
instructed by veterinarian. To be corrected from 8/7/2025 forward.

There is an expired bag of bird food located in the walk-in cooler. It is a large bird diet designed for Macaws, African
greys, Cockatoos, and other large birds that expired on 5/31/2025. Expired food could be contaminated or lack nutritive
value due to deterioration of ingredients over time. Feeding expired food to birds could also cause illness and discomfort.
The food must be wholesome, palatable to the birds, and free of contamination. All expired food should be thrown away
and not fed to the birds. To be corrected by August 14th, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There is an expired tube of Lidocaine and an expired bottle of Levetiracetam in the clinic room in building A. There is also 
an expired bottle of Enalapril Maleate 5mg/ml in the medication prep and storage area in Building C. The Enalapril 
Maleate is prescribed to an umbrella cockatoo named “Katie”. The Enalapril expired on 7/13/25 and is still being 
administered to “Katie”. The use of expired medications is not considered to be a safe or appropriate method to prevent, 
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries since the expected results cannot be guaranteed. The facility must 
ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The licensee must 
ensure all medications used for animals covered under the Animal Welfare Act are not expired. The facility corrected this 
at time of inspection by throwing away all expired medications. 
Treatment sheets for 13 birds show multiple doses of medication prescribed by the attending veterinarian that were not 
recorded as being given. Not giving the medications and supplements on the days and times that they are required could 
lead to unnecessary pain and could further delay healing and resolution of health conditions. The facility must ensure the 
use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries by giving prescriptions as 
instructed by veterinarian. To be corrected from 8/7/2025 forward. 
3.155(a) 
   
Feeding 
There is an expired bag of bird food located in the walk-in cooler. It is a large bird diet designed for Macaws, African 
greys, Cockatoos, and other large birds that expired on 5/31/2025. Expired food could be contaminated or lack nutritive 
value due to deterioration of ingredients over time. Feeding expired food to birds could also cause illness and discomfort. 
The food must be wholesome, palatable to the birds, and free of contamination. All expired food should be thrown away 
and not fed to the birds. To be corrected by August 14th, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
 n
